name: Lyon
fun_fact: Fun fact: Lyon is considered the gastronomic capital of France (yes, even more than Paris), and its traditional bouchon restaurants began in the 17th century feeding silk workers - today, you need to look for the Gnafron marionette sticker on the door to know you've found an authentic bouchon certified by the city.

hero_dishes.name: Quenelles de Brochet
hero_dishes.description: Delicate pike fish dumplings, often swimming in buttery crayfish Nantua sauce - light, elegant, and quintessentially Lyonnais
hero_dishes.origin_story: These ethereal dumplings are Lyon's answer to fine dining. The pike is ground into a mousse, formed into ovals, and poached until tender. The Nantua sauce, made with crayfish, is the crowning glory
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Certified bouchons throughout Lyon, Bouchon L茅a (serving since 1943), La Meuni猫re (nearly 100 years old)

hero_dishes.name: Tablier de Sapeur
hero_dishes.description: Beef tripe marinated overnight in white wine, lemon, and mustard, then breaded and fried until crispy, served with gribiche sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Named after the leather aprons worn by sappers (military engineers), this dish represents Lyon's commitment to nose-to-tail eating. It's an acquired taste that bouchon lovers swear by
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Certified bouchons, Daniel et Denise (chef Joseph Viola, Meilleur Ouvrier de France)

hero_dishes.name: Salade Lyonnaise
hero_dishes.description: Fris茅e lettuce with crispy bacon lardons, croutons, and a perfectly poached egg - simple but exquisite
hero_dishes.origin_story: This salad epitomizes Lyonnaise cuisine - taking humble ingredients and elevating them through technique. The runny egg yolk becomes the dressing when broken
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every certified bouchon, Les Fines Gueules (run by Jo毛l Salzi who trained under Paul Bocuse)

hero_dishes.name: Cervelle de Canut
hero_dishes.description: Fresh cheese mixed with olive oil, garlic, herbs, vinegar, shallots, salt, and pepper - literally 'silk worker's brain' but actually a creamy cheese spread
hero_dishes.origin_story: Named mockingly after the canuts (silk workers) who couldn't afford expensive food, this humble cheese spread is now a point of pride in every bouchon
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Caf茅 du Jura (genuine family institution), certified bouchons as an appetizer

signature_drinks.name: Beaujolais Wine
signature_drinks.description: Light, fruity red wine from the Beaujolais region just north of Lyon - meant to be drunk young and slightly chilled
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in pot Lyonnais (thick-bottomed wine carafes) at bouchons. Beaujolais is Lyon's house wine, consumed liberally with every meal

signature_drinks.name: C么tes du Rh么ne
signature_drinks.description: Rich red wines from the Rh么ne Valley - fuller-bodied than Beaujolais
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with richer dishes like andouillette and tablier de sapeur. Lyon sits at the confluence of the Rh么ne and Sa么ne rivers, with great wine regions in every direction

food_culture_notes: Look for the Gnafron marionette sticker - the 'Les Bouchons Lyonnais' certification created in 2013 for authentic bouchons
Daniel et Denise is owned by chef Joseph Viola, winner of Meilleur Ouvrier de France award
Bouchons are concentrated in La Croix-Rousse and Presqu'le (between the Rh么ne and Sa么ne rivers)
Tarte aux Pralines (pink praline tart) dates back to the 17th century and is fundamental to Lyon's culinary heritage
